reviewText:
Overview
The Escapists is a game about escaping prison. You play as one of the prisoners in a variety of different prisons. Despite its initial appearance, the game has an extreme level of depth and even the prison listed as Very Easy (Center Perks) is hard enough that I have yet to escape.

Speaking of escaping, there are many methods of doing so, but almost anything you do can be traced back to you by the guards. You can steal plastic knives from the cafeteria and cut the vent open in your cell - but they'll trace it to you. You can climb onto the roof - but you'll get sniped by the guards in the towers. You can dig a tunnel towards the outer fence - but you might leave dirt lying around and the warden will have the hole caved in.

You can perform favors for other prisoners to get money, which can be used to buy things from other prisoners. Favors might involve beating down another inmate or taking an item. Many items are illegal (red name) and you will be sent to solitary confinement if you are found with one or one is found in your desk during a cell search.

Life in The Escapists is all about keeping the guards off of you, and to do that, you must follow prison routine. In the morning is roll call - you must attend this or the entire prison will be put into lockdown. You also have a job that you must do. The following is the routine on the first prison, Center Perks:

Morning Roll Call
Breakfast
Free Time
Lunch
Work, or Leisure if unemployed
Exercise
Showers
Evening Meal
Evening Free Time
Evening Roll Call
Lights Out
You also have skills that can be used. Speed determines your attack speed, strength your attack damage, and intellect is your crafting smarts. You find crafting recipes through notes you can buy (or steal from others), and these stats can be raised in different ways but degrade over time.

But this review is getting long, and I don't want to explain every aspect of this game, so let me list off some pros and cons.

Pros
Very in-depth; great variety of items
Large variety; many ways to escape
Flavorful; lots of chatting and makes the prison seem real
Complete feeling; feels like a full game even in early access
Cons
Buggy; sometimes there are bugs, like guards shouting at you to get to work while you are at work or people you can't interact with whatsover, i.e. infirmary staff or the warden
Solitary; if something is traced to you, you go into solitary regardless of current position or state - basically instant, with no opportunity to escape it
Unclear; the game only has a vague tutorial and you must learn on your own, which CAN be fun
Let me tell you a story.
I was a prisoner at the first prison. During the first three days, I made quite a hideout. I made paper mache out of toilet paper and super glue, which I made a fake vent cover out of so I could freely climb up and down the vents without fear of leaving it open. I had a massive storage of illegal supplies, a bludgeoning weapon made out of a sock with soap inside of it, and an outfit with metal plates beneath the cloth. Most of the inmates liked me, and I constantly went around bruising people for pay/

One night, I decided to explore the vents more. I left a dummy made with pillows under the covers of my bed to fool the guards into thinking I was asleep. WIth some floss, I cut through slats in the system and saw a stash on the other side of a vent which I could not bypass. I figured I could cut through the vent and go across.

Wrong.

I fell into the infirmary office. The door was locked, and I hadn't had the foresight to make a key from a mold. In other words, I was trapped, and the infirmary staff always lock the door when they came in. I searched all night for a way through the vent, started chipping through the walls with a screwdriver (which broke), and as the sun rose I resigned to my fate and hid in the supply closet. After morning roll call, the prison went on lockdown. As the confused inmates reported to their cells, I received a notice that the military was on their way to the prison.

After a minute and a half, I was found and thrown into solitary.

Final Score
Very in-depth, great fun, and feels complete though in early access. However, it has some standing flaws and errors which interfere with gameplay.

I rate The Escapists 8/10.

June 6, 2015 update: I still recommend this game. There are a few DLCs which I haven't got around to playing (like the Alcatraz DLC) and it's still quite enjoyable. I'm personally burned out on it, though, and it doesn't offer much outside of the same thing over and over for its price. Wait until it's on sale and it's great value - otherwise, I would skip it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zDR3s-rwR4I&list=PLBqXrq67D6opAYyFG3uBPUlju_GMrN1Bg&index=2

After 7 hours playing The Escapists I have to say it's fun and above all addicting! I'm playing with press access. No matter what route you decide to take, a man of the block prisoner or an educate one, your objective is always the same, escape. There's no wandering for 30 years. Don't let the art style fool you, it is light-hearted but it's challenging as heck. Just like in reality you have to carefully make all your moves and stick to the plan. If something fails you're off to the solitaire, items confiscated and your plan ruined. Fortunately you can load saved games.

Pros
- crafting items, and there's a lot of choices
- save games when you return to the cell at the end of the day
- you just don't run out of things to do, the game encourages you to keep moving
- it's damn challenging
- play it your own way
- it's damn funny watching all the incidents during the day, prisoners will interact with each other

Cons
- the music is repetitive, I had to turn it off and pick my playlist
- no customization, I would like to customize my character other than the name

reviewText:
9.5/10

This game is incredible. Namely, the feeling that you get when you are almost completely sure you've set up everything right, and are about to escape, but you never know if it'll work until you try.

I've left the dummy in the bed, I've knocked out my roomate, I've put the poster back over the hole in the wall, I've taken enough plastic knives to finish cutting the fence, and I didn't forget to put on my guard uniform. But did I remember fatigue? Oh no! I didn't bring any chocolate bars to make it through the night! For this, I'm stuck sawing at the fence until dawn when the snipers come back and knock me out. I'm placed in solitary for a few days. I've missed my chance.

reviewText:
I don't have much time in but I’m writing because my initial reaction was so strong.  I'll say first that I've done two years behind bars in the U.S. and almost four in a community corrections facility.  This game immediately started a mild and pleasant sympathetic nervous response (i.e. fight or flight/adrenaline/epinephrine) because of the very simplified, yet somewhat accurate representation of incarcerated life, with its rigorous, paramilitary lifestyle.  I was immediately reminded of the intense cleaning rituals, endless card games, terrible smells, awful food, and the overall lack of privacy and respect from guards and other inmates.  In light of all this, my first successful escape was EXILARATING AS HELL!  This game will appeal to squares and ex-cons a like!

9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Escapists is a game by Mouldy Toof Studios. It puts you in one of numerous prisons with the simple goal of escaping. But it isn’t as easy as you think, the point of a prison is to keep you in your place, which is what this game does.

You get the choice of one of numerous characters who you can rename, a prison, and the option to name your prisoners if you had a friend you wanted to be with during your life sentence. When it comes to content the game is incredible, there are many different items you can get hold of from soap to post cards. That’s not even all, you can combine items to make more stuff to help you escape; paper mache for fake walls, nunchucks for attacking, key molds, Dummies, glass shanks, fake grates, posters, grappling hooks and so much more!

This game requires lots of planning, you can’t just beat up a guard, take his keys and leave. You need to spend some time exercising to get strong, you need key molds to keep keys or else you get time in solitary, there are guard patrols everywhere and even clogging the toilet with dirt from the hole you’ve been digging. You need to plan how you’re going to escape and balance you actual escape attempt with the prison timetable; eating, sleeping, free time, work and roll call. If you don’t fill your work’s quota then you get fired, complete the quota though and you get money to bribe other prisoners or buy stuff from them.

The actual gameplay itself is really well done, everything is quite solid and the game is most definitely playable. You can choose from many ways to escape, through the vents, underground, through the front door or even starting a riot. The graphics is designed to look 8-bit, a nice look for many games that is also fairly easy to make. The audio in the game is very well made, and if you like the music playing in the background you can get the music from the game’s steam folder.

If you enjoy playing games that require work and planning for you to play and succeed then this is the game for you. I rate this 10/10 in its current Early Access state, it’s a solid game worth the cost to buy it. When it leaves Early Access I don’t think there’s a rating system high enough to grade it… or at least that’s what I think will happen when it leaves Early Access anyway.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What more can you want (Except later updates)?
Escape from prison, in the most strange and familiar ways possible, from digging out with a spoon to beating up all the guards and been allowed to WALK out the prison, helped by the warden.
This game has an incredible range of difficulty:
If you want to escape a prison, then probably return because they have free food, nice guards (Bodyguards almost) and deluxe toliet paper, choose Center Perks.
If you want to (Fail at) escape(ing) prison because they have inmates tougher than the guards (and thats saying something), A personal army armed with stunsticks that knock alomost ANYTHING out with one hit, A small sea and shaving cream then choose HMP Irongate.
Also have glitches and a guard heat that is sometimes very funny:
If you want to get shot in the balls get to breakfast late that one to many times.
If you want to knock out a guard with zero retaliation, do it with a pillow on a certain map (Im not saying which, Bug exploit)
Amazing inmate (And own) comments:
If you want to ask another inmate whether he made friends in the shower room, do it there.
If you want to swear while tring to be sneaky, break a tool while trying to escape steathly (no-one will hear you scream F-)
Weapons that are really awesome.
If you want to wield nunchucks, two timber and a wire
If you want to nearly kill people with soap, put it in a sock
If you want to make a weapon out of just a comb, hit it agaisnt a wall
In short, If you want to have fun, GET THIS GAME!
666 out of 21

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game... I saw it on Steam just a few days after it'd come out for Early Access (20th of August) and I thought it looked really cool. I bought it and wow... My brain just exploded with delight.

If you've ever played Prison Architect, like me, you'll sorta understand how to play this game. But of course you're not building the prison this time, you're ESCAPING IT.
It has a lot of cool mechanics already implemented into it. I won't give you any hints on escaping except you can use screwdrivers on vents.

You can even take your clothes off...

Guards beat you up for it...

But there are a few bugs:

I know I have a bad computer, but this is a Pixelated-Art-Style-Kind-Of-Thing game. Framerate is a bit of an issue for me.
The guard AI can be a bit annoying aswell. Only a bit. Sometimes, when doing Morning Rollcalls, they'll have a lockdown because I didn't get there within five seconds. Then I have all my illegal items taken ;-;

All in all, this game is worth it. DayZ has bugs, but everyone loves it. Minecraft has bugs, but it has grown to be one of the most Let's Play"ed games out there. I really think if you like the idea of this game and it's style
date: you should get it.\n\nIts price will go up later too. Do you really want that regret?"

reviewText:
Do I recommend this? YEAH I DO!

The Escapists is a game where you are thrown into prison. You must escape the prison, and believe me, that's not easy.
Now, I'm going to be honest and give my pros and cons:
~Updated Review~

Pros:
- Lots of prisons, and cheap extra prison DLC.
- Devs listen to us (community)
- Amazing art style.
- Challenging, you have to be smart to escape, as it isn't easy.
- Lots of items and tons of item combos.
- Lots of favorites for inmates.
- Map editor + submission to workshop.
- A semi-realistic prison feel.
- Soundtrack is great! There are new songs during free periods.
- Inmates speeches are pretty funny. (personal pro for me)
- Multiple ways to escape. (Ex: first prison has about 3 (+) ways to escape!)
- Custom inmate names, and choosable skins.

Cons:
- Lots of waiting, and can get very boring if you're not patient.
- Cops / guards catch you easily. This makes a challenge, though!
- Gets repetitive once in a while, but DLC makes up for it.
-

So, if you like prison games and have a lot of patience, then this is for you. My old review can be seen below, and I decided to update it as the game has updated a lot since then.

Final Score: 8.5/10

~Old Review~

Pros:
- Great art style. (32 bit?)
- Soundtrack is great. Every prison has their own free time song that plays.
- Challenging.
- Tons of items.
- Multiple, and I mean multiple escape routes. The first prison has over 3 escape routes!
- Favors are really easy to do.
- Inmates' speeches are pretty darn funny.
- Developers actually listen to us (the community)
- Each prison offers new items and layouts, and gets tougher each time.
- Map Editor!
- Has a realistic prison theme.

Cons:
- None, go buy the game! (If you haven't.)

That's my short review.

reviewText:
Chipping trough walls with plastic forks. Crafting make-shift weapons. Scouting out the prison. Getting the right items. Dodging guards. Living prison life. Getting keymolds. Getting better jobs. Leveling stats. Getting a guard outfit. Covering up dug holes and chipped walls. Finnaly getting out to the perimiter wall. Get shot by a guard in a tower, taking all your items and putting you into solitary. Trying again. Succes. Reliazie this was the easiest prison, and a even harder one awaits you.

Sounds like fun? It is fun.

Pros:

- 6 defualt prisons, along side 2 custom. (3 if you had early acces)
- A sea of non-craftable and craftable items.
- A easy to understand crafting system.
- A helpfull and lovely community.
- Amazing soundtrack.
- The abillity to name all guards and in-mates.
- 9001 ways to escape the prison.
- Very polished and alsmost bug free.
-PRISON EDITOR

Cons:


- Very rage inducing.


So all in all, The Escapist is an amazing game and should be played at all costs. Fun and compelling, challenging and extrmely high quality. Easy to get into, hard to master. Well, I am off to see if my plan works this time.

10/10

reviewText: The Escapists is without a doubt one of the best games I have ever played. The game is all about trying to escape a prison. While that might seem like a simple task (because it's a videogame, not real life), it's actually quite challenging. The game has a surprisingly deep strategy behind it, as you have to plan many things while maintaining a varying prison schedule. It has many tense moments that grasp the player into a deep concentration and fills him/her with excitement and anxiety that only this kind of game can produce. The developers have also confirmed a level editor where you can create your own prisons and support for multiplayer. However, one should, if he/she plays the game blindly, notice the brutal learning curve, as this game can barely be played without help from a video or a wiki. But, that doesn't stop me from recommending this game to one of my peers.  If you can, buy it now, and you'll see how it's definitely worth the money.

reviewText:
Key supplied by developer for review.
======================================The Escapists Read on for full review!
======================================
TL;DR:
BUY IT. Great tutorial, good music, fun and extremely immersive gameplay.
Accessible as heck, but with depth.

======================================
Pros+UI: Great layout, simple, intuitive.
+Graphics: Who doesn't love some nice pixel art? Great light/shade/colors.
+Sound: A bit chunky, but good, retro, immersive.
+Gameplay: One of the most immersive games I've played

Cons-None so far!

Neutral+/- Settings: Only so many, and sliders can't be dragged! Nbd for me.

======================================
So The Escapists is essentially a time management/prison lifestyle sim. This game is a delight! The graphics are very good, and serve their purpose well. Areas are distinct, everything has light, shadow, and a suitable color. The pixel art is very well done. The sprites are cute, and some of them realistic for their size. Also, every object is distinct. The UI is 100% serviceable, with distinct colors and objects of its own, and just the right amount of polish.

The tutorial, also, is amazing. It's quick, easy, and gives you a nice step by step introduction to the world with a step by step instructionset, without spoiling the deeper elements to the game such as crafting recipes. The gameplay is equally as accessible, everything being a simple tap, right click, or left click away...and maybe a few alternating keys. You can customize the controls, but I'm not sure why you'd ever need to! It makes me think of the Sims, except you are playing the character, and you choose what to do. There is an ASTONISHING amount of freedom in gameplay. You can blend in, you can sneak off, you can build your stats, or trade contraband with the inmates. Start fights. Steal. Do favors, or EVEN your job! The list goes on!! But your primary goal is of course to escape, and on that note, the AI is responsive, so you better be ready. I've encountered no bugs so far.

The music is serviceable, and that's about it. It isn't intrusive, it isn't bad, but it isn't amazing. It works for the setting and I definitely like it, but I don't completely love it. The sound effects are basic and perhaps slightly jarring at times.

The only issues I've had with the game are the lack of resolution settings, and some desks not wanting to leave my arms easily. The RNG can create some unforgiving wait times, but it also makes things a bit intense and there's a lot of anticipation. This game has actually made me feel anxious, and gotten my heart beating at times!

There are all kind of custom maps the community has made, which can offer a unique flavor or new twist or challenge, which is nice. On a related final note, the difficulty is present, with the game leaving it up to you how you want to escape, as well as how to do some of the things required to do just that, but once you figure it out, the prisons difficulty scales quite nicely.

All in all, I've never so quickly felt so at home in a game.

Now if only I could find that dental floss... ;)

======================================
If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

reviewText: Edit: Before I edited this review (See original at the bottom of this review) I took it in a humorous manner, but now, I want to actually speak about the gameplay mechanics and features.\nTo start out, when you open the game, you  can either play the game or open the map editor (Which is an exceptional addition, but I'll get to that later). Once you have opened the game you get the usual intro of about 3 logos or so, real fast, then you're on to the main menu. Start a new file, pick a prisoner, name that prisoner (optional, default names are provided), then, just like a snap of the fingers, you're in prison for whatever reason. You have one main goal: escape. You have many ways to escape the prison/camp, but each prison/camp varies in difficulty. You can tunnel out most prisons, cut through them, and. if so you wish, take some nunchaku (NunChucks), knock out every guard and just walk out the place.\nThere is more to the game than meets the eye. Under the nostalgic 16-bit graphics, you have a complicated, yet easily understandable game. There are very many crafting recipes, and yes, I know what you are thinking, Oh no
date: another clone trying to rip off the ol' MineCraft crafting mechanic..." But that is not how the crafting works. Sure
recommended: you collect items to make something new
hoursPlayed: but you're not making furnaces or desks
voteText: or even beds. You are making your means of escape. After you have made your contraband through the detectors
helpfulPercent: to your room

reviewText:
The escapists is a extremely fun game, with a good art style, challenging, fun and rewarding gameplay, 8 free prisons, good music, a prison creator, a infinite amount of player created prisons, and lots of getting caught.
there are also three prisons that cost real money, but they are well designed and have some exclusive content.

The game is a little confusing at first, so beware.

This game will (probably) make you cry. If they are tears of joy or tears of sadness depends on the circumstance.
Just try not to get caught, use the wiki and guides and you might make it out alive.

reviewText:
Like some mind-bending combination of MYST and every classic top-down RPG in history, the Escapists manages to blend heart pounding moments of adrenaline and reaction, with cerebral activities, in a well paced fashion.

Long and careful hours of scheming, conniving, poisoning, sabotaging, exploring, manipulating, and chipping away (literally) at your confinement, sit side by side with vicious scrums and scraps.

What makes this game so amazing is that it gives you the chance to live out that mental fantasy where you imagine that you could do a better job of breaking out of jail than any number of TV or Movie characters (or even real-life felons).  Ironically for a game about being imprisoned, this game provides true freedom;  Freedom to piece together your own unique plan of escape.

The game is quite robust in terms of replayability, very stable (no crashes or bugs so far in my playthroughs), and requires very little by way of system resources.  It will, however, tax your brain, your wit, and your reflexes, in the best way.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off you DO NOT NEED A PROCCESSOR EQUIVLANT TO THE RECOMMENDED. I have a dual core cpu that runs at 1.65 Ghz no where near the recomended 2.4 Ghz and it runs flawless for me. This game could probably be ran on a a single core processor.

If you like building prisons in the amazing Prison Architecht you will love this  game! It might look like a childish/retro 8-bit game, but think again. In this game you are forced to use your brain to the brink of it's processing power. Along with escaping you have to make it to roll call's 3 times a day, eat 3 times a day, exercise 1 time a day, shower 2 times a day, and work once a day if you have a job. If you do not manage your time wisely and are able to keep with the schedule you will not escape.

There are more ways to escape then I can count. You can dig, use the vents and roof, cut through fences, break through walls, steal keys and more. You usually have to use multiple different things out of those to be able to espcape.  There are tons of items also that you can craft to help you escape. Along with these items you can only craft them if you have a high enough intellect and in order to get and keep it up you have to work out your mind each day.

You have to be super sneaky or the guards will catch you off guard and throw you into solitary. If you get thrown into solitary they will search all your stuff and take any contraband and you will have to start over which at times comletely screws you up and can be esier to start over.

This game is full of stuff to do and has hours upon hours of gameplay and it's only in early access! I just barely escaped for the first time! It took me 15 hours! This game is complex and amazingly hard which gives it that super fun experience and the amazing feeling of accomplishment when you finaly escape!

I reccomend this game to anyone and say it is 100% worth the price! To all of you reading this, BUY THIS GAME!!!

reviewText:
The idea is great, but the game gets so annoying because of instabusts.

You just took over the prison and the warden said you made your point and you're free to go? Well, hopefully nobody finds contraband in your desk now, because if they do it's a one-way-ticket to solitary without you being able to do anything against that. You get a message and bam. Try again. Stole a key from a guard? Oh yeah. As soon as they wake up they know it was you and they also instantly know where you are. To the solitary!

I also just dug a tunnel. Over 50 tiles. Took me more than 3 ingame weeks and required ♥♥♥♥ ton of duct tape. My only problem was the electrical fence. So I dug to the generator room. counted tiles. I wait for the night, want to dig up to shut down the generator. But nope: As soon as my hole is open I get a message that a tower guard spotted it and that I have to go to solitary. Yeah. Thanks. Do they have X-Ray vision and are able to look into ♥♥♥♥ing buildings?

Stuff like this really ruins the game, as it really restricts you in what you can do and it doesn't even make any sense the way they did that. Why not let the guards order a shakedown when they notice a key is missing? Search every cell and prisoner. This would at least give you some time to maybe frame another prisoner for stealing it or give you the last few seconds you need to escape. And it would be more realistic and less annoying. The way it is it feels more like an adventure with the solution predetermined by the developers. If I want to dig a 100 tile tunnel to escape you should at least honor that I did that instead of throwing me into solitary with a ♥♥♥♥ing message.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Escapists is a brilliant little title that is well worth the money even in it's early access stage.
The aim of the game is simple, you must escape from your prison but it's not as simple as just waiting til the guards backs are turned and making a wild dash for it.
You start in a prison with various other inmates and are told the basics (WASD to move, right click to interact, left click to use) and from then on out, you're on your own. Each day has a schedule which you will need to follow including rollcalls, mealtimes, worktime and freetime in order to keep the guards off your back. Whilst following the daily schedules you have the ability to do favours for other inmates earning money and boosting their opinion of you, workout or read to increase your skills (making you a more proficient fighter or able to apply for better jobs and craft better items), or plan your escape. You can choose to keep a low profile and gather the items you need for your escape or you can beat the crap out of everyone who looks at you funny and spend half your game in the infirmary,
The game already has a variety of features such as crafting, basic skill building, various jobs, legal and contraband items, fatigue levels and 'friendship' levels with other inmates. There seems to be various different way to escape and in the 4 hours i've played i've not been bored once which is always a good sign for an Early Access game.

I think the game is worth the small price tag, and even if you don't plan on buying it yet, 100% keep your eye on it, its truly a game with great potential.

reviewText:
As I had the privilege of meeting Chris Davis this weekend at Insomnia 54 (nice guy!), I thought I'd take the time to leave my thoughts.

An awesome prison simulator, with an old-school twist. Hours of fun to be had.

Each prison appears to have a well defined strategy, although alternative methods can be carried out (e.g. beating up all of the prison guards, molding gate keys., etc) Different prisons have a different routine to follow and it is vital that you get to know this routine in order to plan your escape successful. For example, a 10am rollcall must be attended to ensure the guards don't get suspicious that you're upto no good.

Clearly a lot of thought went into the crafting system. Items can be combined to make new ones that you will need in order to escape from the prison of choice.

I completely love the whole 8-bit vibe that The Escapists has going on. Old school graphics and old school sound effects help set the tone very well.

The only bug I've personally found in this game is when getting my intellect to 100 by browsing the internet at the computer in the first prison, the achievement did not unlock for me.  I did get the chance to mention this to Chris, so I'm hoping this will get sorted out soon, if it hasnt been addressed already.

All in all, buy this game if you like challenging, stategic thinking and are looking for a game that will keep you engrossed for ages! (Drop the soap.)

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game.  The concept is super cool, and the fact that it's basically a puzzle game is very interesting, but the gameplay itself doesn't have any soul.  It too often feels like work.  Very little of what you have to do is intuitive, specifically the crafting and how you are meant to interact with the environment.  Items have no descriptions to indicate their potential functions.  Characters are just pawns to manipulate, you can't really interact with them in a meaningful way to glean info on how the game works, what might be going on in your prison, or what you might be able to do with them (on top of them being personally indistinguishable from one another).

I too often just had to look something up to see if I could do it, and if I could, how, because it was rarely obvious.  For example, I knocked out a guard and immediately tried what I knocked him out for: making a mold of his key using my soap bar.  Nope.  Or how about making the key using the correct mold - molten plastic?  Got a lighter and a plastic fork and - nope.  Plastic has to come from a comb or toothbrush, I discovered when I looked it up.  Alternatively, I could pay my character's money to use the payphone to get randomized hints about what to do, but why can't I just glean this info from playing the game? It is otherwise simply not there.

The stats for your character also feel like artificial blockades, and why they degrade I'm not really sure.  I don't want to spend 3 minutes clicking one spot in order to get smarter, or pressing the Q and E keys over and over to get stronger or faster.  It's just not fun, so why have it?  The worst part is you don't level these stats up in any other way besides the exercise task or the reading task, so you are forced to engage in these activities.  Increasing these stats based on what quests you complete would have been a good idea, or based on moving around the prison, but it doesn't work that way - you must exercise or read, which amounts to wasting time both in-game and in real life.  Nothing quantified how I feel about this game better than clicking the bookshelf and watching the reading" meter fill up over the course of a couple seconds.

When the game works
date: it works very well. Attempting an escape is thrilling and got my pulse going. It's just the process of getting there that is not fun. I don't want to have to have a browser window open when I can't figure out why I can't combine a pillow and a prison outfit to make a bed dummy
recommended: or why the entrance key won't let me out of the prison
hoursPlayed: and for that matter what these colored locks mean and why I have to actually obtain the keys to them before I can even see their names.\n\nThis game feels like it was designed by people who are very comfortable with having a browser window open in crafting and survival games
voteText: as though that's just the accepted reality of these games.  That's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ reality

reviewText: I absolutely love this game. From planning your escape to the rush of putting your plot to work, it's amazing throughout. It's fun to try and find ways to hide your contraband from the guards and ways to smuggle materials from people and jobs to your desk. It's also really crushing if the guards find out what you're planning... But if they don't, the rush of escaping is insane. Regardless of how boring it must look to see someone cutting through vent grates or digging under a fence, it had my heart pounding, especially if a guard just happened to wonder by me. Overall, I think this game is awesome and it's worth your time and money.

reviewText:
The Escapists is one of the most enjoyable games I have ever played. I could honestly play this game all day. If you like any of the following, this game is for you!
-Prison Simulators
-Prison Escape
-Escaping
-RPG
-Pixel Graphics
-Addicting Games
-Strategy
-Single-Player
-Schedules
-Fun
-Simulation
-Being Sneaky
-Statistics
-Variety
-Character Customization (Picking a character)
-Renaming Characters
-Recruiting prisoners to team up with you in your escape
-Jobs (Not IRL)
-Training
-Crafting
-Inventories
-Managing storage space
-Organizing
-Tasks/Missions
-Trading
-Shopping
-Realism (somewhat)
-Keeping yourself occupied
And other things...

The one thing that would make this game even better would be a multiplayer feature.

Personal Rating:
★★★★☆

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The escapists, a game I love more than a band of bassists.

The escapists of course is about prison life, where you are the source of a lone lunatic with a knife. Attempting to escape from a desolate jail, in desperate need of a quick bail. The gameplay is simple; you need to breakout no matter how many guards/prisoners you’re required to takeout.

I admire the options, no matter how dire like hanging from a wire. You can dig out, but if the prison is big it won't end well with me and my mate dizon arisen from the dirt, only to appear in the middle of the yard in fear and sniper fire.

You can cause a riot when things've gotten quiet, but certainly hard when I kept losing my teeth in the yard.

Or more fun escape via roof, while under pursuit before getting stomped by the guard’s practical hoof.

All in all I can't comment much more beyond that, the involvement of this game is like a torrent of vomit, a spice rack of chunks of what was a good snack, but with an oversized wallet locked away in the closet it becomes quite worth it.

Otherwise can recommend.

reviewText:
EDIT:  This review is very outdated, and since the addition of the white locked doors, this no longer works.


I have created the best strategy at beting this game.  Ever.
It took me only 27 minutes to beat it, and I beat it at lunch of Day 3.

The problem is everyone thinks of the most elaborate scheems ever to beat the game (through the vent, digging underground, etc.)  But this plan is simple, and I mean SIMPLE.  All you have to do is collect a few things:

1. Tub of talcum powder
2. Toothpaste
3. Comb/Toothbrush
4. Lighter
5. Somewhat good weapon

After collecting these things your going to require at least 80 intel so you can craft the tub of talcum powder and toothbrush into a wad of putty,  then use the lighter and comb/toothbrush to make molten plastic.  After doing so get at least 35 health (70 strength), and around 40 speed or so.

Now that you've got all the hard work done, it's time for the fun part.  You're going to beat up gaurds until you have the one with a staff key, if he doesn't have the red staff key, don't take it.  When you find the one with the red staff key take it off him, and combine the key with the wad of putty.  and it is EXTREMELY imortant that after you make the staff key mold you put the real staff key back on him.  If you don't do so you will lose all your items.  Now you have a staff key mold.  craft the staff key mold with the molten plastic So you will get a plastic staff key.  Once you have this you're ready to escape.  All you have to do is when the guards are doing rolecall (So 3 of them are occupied, and 2 are guarding)  You run out the front door,  select the staff key,  click one of the doors with a red lock with you're plastic staff key, and  run out the unlocked door to freedom.

If you've read this far, thanks for taking the time to read this quick guide to win easy, and I hope it helps!

reviewText:
This is a great strategy game for anyone who wants to test their mental limit in planning and scheming.
The map editor needs to be improved though, as it is missing some important parts (if they're already in place and I'm just missing them, please tell me):
1) More selectable zones, specifically: library, mailroom, cells 11-20, infirmary, officer quarters, and employment offices.
2) More wall/fence options, like a four-way path and more three-way paths (up-left-right and up-down-left missing).
3) Some kind of tutorial or guide, or at least more detailed/clearer info when you hover over the objects.
I also feel like there should be a way to save or quick save during the day, since players currently need to play through an entire day before being able to save their game.

reviewText: Now, I have only played around 15 of the games in my library of a somewhat comparatively larger 54, but boy am I glad that this is one of the games I play. Now, much like a lot of my games, if it's not tf2 I dont play it often. This stands for this game as well, though it is extremely enjoyable. The amount of luck that can go into the earlier prisons (note my day 2 escape) and the amount of skill the later ones take is one of the defining factors that makes this game stand out to me. It was quite small whilst it was coming up to its release, but many youtubers shifted popularity onto this gem and I would like to thank them. And hey, naming prisoners after your friends and seeing how they react in the new life, at the end of the day, is broderline enjoyable. It's like if sims was in a prison except not sims... Wait what? Ok, what I meant to say was it's nice to kick back to prison life and try and escape the prisons. The dialogue is also filled with references, so make sure to read em' all! I rate it a 7/10

reviewText:
When i first got this game, I thought it was pretty fun. But as i played further, the game really lost its charm and became really boring. There are really no fun ways of escaping, and for the most part, escaping is impossible unless you google how to do it. If there was a way to organize an escape with other inmates, this game would be leaps and bounds greater. But of course the other inmates are pretty useless for anything other than items. You always see the same few jokes that have lost their novelty 1 or 2 hours into the game, and talking to them only gets your respect up. That respect doesn't translate into them helping you in fights or building a gang; it only makes their comments change to a happier tone. They don't give you tips on how to escape, you cant task them to do your dirty work... The disconnect between NPC and the player is so frustratingly low. I hate the fact that the game feels less like a prison and more like an endless challenge with no real satisfaction.

TL;DR - the game is a great concept, but it lacks complexity that would make you really immerse with the world. The disconnect between player and NPC is so large, it is actually frustrating. Its not worth your money, honestly.

3/10
PS: I bought this game back when it was Early Access, but i have played the full release version. My opinion still stands.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been waiting for this game ever since it came out on greenlight over a year ago, checking each month to see what progress was made. Let me just say that this game was worth the wait. I am a big fan of 'pixel games' and this game is no exception. The game has captured the theme of living in a prison very well, making you want to escape from the dreadful prison!

This game very enjoyable as is both fair and difficult. Although it can be a real challenge to escape the prison, the general gameplay is simple and lets you choose how you want to play. With very simple guidlines and controls, you get a hang of the game in a flash. You can either escape through the vents, tunnel underground, obtain fake keys or now, with the new update, beat down all of the guards! The escaping part of the game is the hardest and very intense.

This game does currently have only 1 prison to escape from, but I am sure that there will be more prisons in the future as they are frequently updating the game. The most recent update allowed more ways to escape as well as new uniforms to enhance the way you play. The crafting aspect of the game is incredible. With countless things availiable to craft, you can either discover the vast diversity of crafting through crafting notes, or steam guides :). With the developers working on the game at an outstanding pace, there will for sure be way more crafting options, as well as new items, then there are now.

Games with good AI are the ones that stand out for me, and this is one of them. The prisoners have their own way of doing things with there personal opinion on you. They may fight you if you have done things that they don't like which have stacked up, or join you in fighting guards if you help them enough. They have challenges for you which you can do for money, in which you can buy vital items you need to escape with. I'm am sure with the new updates that come that these inmates will continue to become more intelligent and my even try to escape from you.

Being a Prison Architect fan, the idea of being an actual prisoner inside the game itself was fasinating. This game really pulled it off well, as the gameplay, AI and content all added up to this game being a thriving success. This game will continue to get better and better as the updates continue to improve the game. It deserves more popularity that is has in my opinion.

Overall Score 9/10

reviewText:
Wow, what a great game. And I mean it.

The Escapists is a good original game, that focuses on escaping a prison. The prison's get harder and harder (obviously) but you actually need to think of ways to escape and actually use your brain for this game. Try playing the game without using it. You won't succeed.

Anywho. The controls for this game are hard to understand and are complicated at first glance but becomes very easy to use and understand afterwards. It makes learning a difficult process but makes the process worth it. Just try to buy the game, although I haven't seen any sales for it recently. I got it for $15 and I think its worth it.

Its actually been a long while since a game has got me so tense when succeeding/escaping. It gives you chills or nerves when your about to escape and a guard comes by you. It makes the whole game a nervewracking worthness. Its put in a 32-bit like pixels although it could be 48-bit.

9/10 Ducks

reviewText:
This game is super cool and intense as hell. The learning curve is of an acquired taste, and there's a lot of trial and soul-and-progress-shattering error but it's well worth it and is a better experience for it.

Sometimes you'll fail a lot just trying to work out the rules of the game and I can see how some would find that frustrating. But I still generally respect the decision to lean the design in this direction.

If you find yourself tempted to look up crafting recipes via Wiki's etc I would advise you to try not doing so, and simply allow yourself to be immersed in this fun little prison life sim and start putting ideas together just as I suppose you really would if you we're planning some kind of daring escape! Try things out and experiment, the recipes and working ideas i've discovered just by putting two and two together were incredibly rewarding, infact so were the recipes that you get out of finding and acquiring crafting notes".

There's an immense sense of satisfaction in finally making your first escape after 28+ days of learning the game inside of the first prison. It feels very real and rewarding and triumphant in a way not many games can offer. Because of how open the game is
date: the plan you make is your plan and will in some way be probably quite different to everyone elses plan. I got very invested in my first escape when I finally committed to "making a break for it".\n\nIt's also jusssst accessible and forgiving enough
recommended: with _just_ stupid enough AI to make the player feel reasonably comfortable with experimenting and trying out crazy ideas. A very difficult balance to get right.\n\nAwesome game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is great. It is in-depth, difficult, and overall fun. Fun fact, I actually almost donated to the project almost a year before it made the Steam Greenlight. Actually, this was the first greenlight game i'd ever approved of. I bought it as soon as i had enough money.
9.5/10
Pros1. Very in-depth.
The prisons you play in almost feel like a real prison.
2.Good Developer
The developer is constantly adding to the game, this game is very well-kept. I reported a bug about your character literally not being able to get out of their bed if you loaded the game in the same session you already played in, and they fixed it within two weeks.
3.Wide Variation of items
I actually had to consult the forum to get some of these ideas! Who would've thought of molten hot chocolate? not me! This game has a surprisingly accurate crafting system as well.
Cons1. This game is still early access
This game is unfinished, so if you don't like changes being made to a game while you play, it isn't for you.
2. The questing system needs work
The game has a well-implemented crafting system, but sometimes you get glitched quests that don't acknowledge when you complete them. This is an issue sometimes, as i'll beat up Officer David,  and then i won't get paid. Also, duplicate quests, (i.e. bob and joe both want officer cooper beat up), means that I have to beat up officer cooper twice, beating him up once only honors one request.
3.The game has a massive difficulty spike.
There needs to be less of a spike between the first and second prisons. End of story.
4.Duplicate Items
A lot of items are basically the same except in crafting. For example, the screwdriver and the crowbar are identical in purpose and value. I would like to see both items work differently.
Things i'd like to see1.Co-Op
This is the huge feature i'd like. Team up, or perhaps go against your friends to make escaping the same prison a new adventure.
2.Prison Editor
I'm aware this is a planned feature, but the sooner you add it the better.

reviewText:
I've played this game for a few hours, I'm gonna tell you what I think about it.

Let's get the con's out of the way, shall we?
- Very hard. When you try to escape, you need to make sure every guard is gone. If you want to dig your way out, you need to have a tunnel short-term. Not having and underground tunnel long-term, because everything will be gone, even your other stuff you used to escape.
- Crafting is very hard, your need to find crafting recepies and you need to higher your intellect or you can't craft stuff.
- Your stats increase slowely, keeping your stats at the right place is hard and requires valuable time you need to have to escape.
- Guards will dislike everything you do (Not being on the right place on the right time, standing on table's, looting stuff etc.)

Let's dump all the negativity and move on with the pro's:
+ Very well scripted, you have different periods (You need to finish your job, have meal, train, etc.)
+ This game has humour
+ Very addicting (Because you fail everytime, you want to try again :P).
+ Community is ok. Some immature people, some nice people.
+ Missions and different ways to earn money.
+ Every thing you make or do, feels rewarding.
+ A lot of items.
+ Workshop, all these maps are amazing.

Overall: 7/10, not for everyone. If you don't like 2D games I suggest to you that you won't like this game. The con's are the reason this rating has -3 points. The game is very hard, even in the most Easy prison available.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game, though it may not look like much, is much harder than one would expect. Even on the easiest prison, every move you make must be carefully calculated. You're gonna need to make sure you keep an eye on your heat to make sure you take on the more appropriate jobs. Hunting down the people selling things can be a hassle, and doesn't always end with good results in terms of buyable products. You have to be extremely careful to leave no evidence, the guards find even a small chip in the wall and it's off to solitary and reset progress. It's important to find a place to store your contraband before you overstock on it. Schedules are important, miss a day of work and you're out of work. This is a game I recommend to anybody who enjoys strategy games.

reviewText:
The Escapists is a puzzle and sandbox game which tasks you with escaping several different prisons (each getting harder than the last).

I personally found this game to be very enjoyable, the game gives you plenty of ways to escape from a prison, giving the game a strong sandbox feel and high replay value. Don't expect to get out of prison on your first run fast though (unless you look at some guides), it takes a long time to find the right moment to take action, but you are rewarded with a strong sense of accomplishment once you leave the stone fortress behind.

Gameplay: The Escapists has a rich and deep system of ways to escape and content within the game. As stated earlier, there is plenty of different ways to escape from a prison. I like the way they incorporated your character's stats; you have to regularly train your character's ablities (going to the exercise room, reading, etc.) to improve your capabilites and keep your stats up high. It prevents simply maxing out all your stats and leaving the prison easily. The crafting system is complex and interesting, but I find it rather annoying that you have to buy the crafting notes from inmates (when one could simply use the wiki). Combat is rather boring, as it's simply a question of who is stronger/has a better weapon. This is easily forgiven though as combat is not the aim of the game.

Graphics: The graphics is a simple yet charming 2D art style. You can really see the amount of detail that went into the art.

Technical: Much to my delight, I have had absolutely zero technical issues (framerate, crashing, etc) with the game so far.

Music: Simple and rather bland. Most of the time it just acts as an ambience. While it's not terrible, don't expect an amazing soundtrack.

Final Score: The Escapists is a rich and rewarding game that is defiantly worth your time, although it may be a bit pricey for an early access game, it defiantly already is at a stage of completion with a few small issues and improvements that could be made.

EDIT: I am very happen to see the release of the prison editor and (extremely cheap) DLC for the game. Boosts my overall score to 8.8.

8.8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overview:

This being my first game to purchase on steam, I would say it was a very good investment. The Escapists has given me countless ours of fun and enjoyment. From beating up guards to smuggling contraband around the prison, I've really had a blast with this game and hopefully I can convince you that it is too.  :)

First Impressions:

I found out about this game by a youtuber called Paulsoares Jr. who sometimes tries out new games on steam. It seemed like a great game; he had lots of fun with it and gave lots of tips and ultimately showed me how to play before I purchased it. I had never seen anything quite like this pixelized prison game, so I decided to scrape up the *ten bucks and give it a go. *The game price has risen a bit

How do I play?:

When playing The Escapists, I was helped very much by the in-game tips and by pressing F1, I could see all of the controls; although, it would be helpful if it would have told me more about things like: opinion and how to earn it; and beating up guards and prisoners.

Pros:
-only $10.00, very worth it *shortly after I bought it, the price rose, but it is still very worth it in my opinion*
-tons of crafting items
-many different ways to escape


Cons:
-the game is early access so the game is uncomplete and there are some bugs
-no multiplayer
-sometimes pretty unbalanced in that if you get caught, all of your hard work goes away :(

Summary:

I would over all rate this game an 8.5 and I hope you give it a go as I did, I promise you won't regret it!
voteText: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Prison Simulator in old-style. In one word: awesome.
The game is playable in early access, even though has *some* game-breaking glitches (going through walls and getting stuck), but when you start playing it, you get pulled in.

Day after day, you do your daily jail routine, help your mates, steal, work, beat up people, collecting materials for your ultimate goal: The Escape. It isn't easy, and you've got little time, but when (and IF) you manage to escape, the feeling is awesome. The game allows you to finish it as fast as 1 in-game day, or play for a long time and become the master of your prison, going anywhere you want and doing anything you'd ever think about. The only things, that I feel, like the game lacks now, is multiplayer and steam workshop, for maps/characters.

TL;DR - Awesome game even in early access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Quite a realistic way to simulate a prison break. You fight with guards, they'll remember and beat you up everytime they see you, until they've actually beaten you up (I think this is a glitch currently). Beat up other inmates, their opinions towards you decreases . Make their opinions low enough, they'll start attack you when they see you alone in a corner. do favor for the inmates, their opinions towards you increases, and you can recruit them to join you as a gang.

It feels like it's going to be a long run, not short game, as what you'd expect a prison escape simulator should be. You need to slowly build up your way in order to break out. Tools must be made yourself, and if you dig, you need to remember to flush out the dirt. And yes, there's no guarantee your toilet is functional, if you're in bad luck the toilet will just get clogged.

I'm on day 24, and trying for a shawshank redemption breakout, playing cool with everyone else while silently solo planning on a breakout. We'll see

reviewText:
This is a review for version 1.0, I will be updating this as the devs update the game, respectively
Overview In The Escapists, you play an unfortunate prisoner, who ends up in prison for doing simple things like murdering your family or eating all the cake in the town. As a prisoner, you go about your daily prison routine to avoid drawing suspicion from the guards, all while plotting your escape. You start out in the most luxurious of prisons, gradually advancing to crummier and more difficult ones as you escape each one. There are many different ways of escaping, and the prison life is well simulated.

Overall Rating: 7/10 A seemingly simple prison escape game that offers a lot of gameplay for very little hard drive space. It's a nice casual/strategy game to play to get away from the other games Steam has to offer. Although, like many relatively new games, could use some improvements.

Price:7/10 The original price of this game in Early Access was $9.99 USD, which is what I purchased it at. Since then, the price has steadily rose due to various game expansions and improvements the developers have implemented and has settled at a reasonable $19.99 USD. Even at $20, the developers are continuing to plan and add new features, making it well worth the price.

Gameplay:9/10 As I've mentioned before, this game offers a surprising amount of gameplay for the little amount of hard drive space it requires. So, in the game you play as a prisoner who has to follow the daily prison routines (rollcall, eating meals, shower, exercise period, lights out, etc). While doing so, however, you must also plot your escape, utilizing various seemingly ordinary objects (duct tape, socks, files, etc) to make the tools in which you need to escape (pickaxes, weapons, shovels, etc). You can gain those items by looting your fellow prisoners' desks or simply purchasing them with money (yes, they give money to prisoners!) There are also many methods of escape, which range from accessing the air vents, tunneling your way out, pretending to be a prison guard, and organizing a prison riot. All these keep a player entertained while enjoying the pleasures of prison life.

Length: 9/10 In Early Access, there were very little guides. I had to figure out all the crafting recipes myself, figure out all the methods of escape myself, and spent many hours just learning the game. Now, in addition to the new content that the devs have provided us for the full release, you can easily rack up over 20+ hours just trying to escape all 6 prisons. That's not all, you can spend even more time trying to get the achievements, if that's what you do.

Story: 4/10 In short, the stories and text in this game are mediocre. The reason I have it as 4/10 as supposed to a 1/10 is because of the witty banter. When you see a prisoner or guard or warden or staff, you often will see them saying a humorous line or two. Things like I should drop you right here" or "My baton does the talking" or "Address me as your king" or even "Taking your wife out to dinner". I would suggest that each prisoner and guard have their own personal diary

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[Day: 1]Aw well, saw it coming a mile away...Mikey stuck me up for an apparent 'murder' which I did not commit. The evidence looked solid but wasn't true, well we'll see how he likes it when I get out of here and give him a suprise visit...

[Day: 5]Thank god the guys here are friendly, seems the prison is filled with crackjobs but heck they sure do give a guy what he needs. Met a guy called Spy, nice french guy gotta' admit. He's been supplying me with some goodies to help me outta' this dump. Should be out in a week or so at this rate.

[Day: 7]Weakened the vent in my cell and I'm rather suprised nobody has heard me unscrewing the damn thing. Unfortunetly my plan can't go yet, nobody has had any supply of ducktape in a while so I've gotta' lay low for a few days before I can put my plan into full flow.

[Day: 15]Spy has went quiet and hasn't been supplying noffin' seems the other inmates have it in for him. A lot of the other lads keep asking me to pummel the guy for dosh...Poor lad, might have to.

[Day: 32]Seriously...No duck tape yet.

[Day: 45]JESUS HOW HARD IS IT TO BRING IN CONTRABAND DUCK TAPE!? They can bring in drugs and knives but they can't even bring in freakin' ducktape!?! You know how hard it is to eat something that feels like dried concrete powder going down your throat? PRETTY DAMN HARD! Starting to lose it...

[Day: 50]Attempted escape plan without the shovel...Improvised with a plastic spoon I took during evening meal. Ended up taking a full sniper shot to the leg, spending time in the medical room...

[Day: 52]...I give up, I'll spend the next 6 years of my sentence waiting for ducktape.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Escapists is a ingenuitive game. I haven't seen many like it, so the originality impresses me. Moreover, the gameplay is intriguing- you're constantly on your toes, hoping the guards won't search your- oh damn, too late, they searched my cell!
The crafting system holds nearly endless possibilites, and the excercizing/reading system has my fingers on thier toes (pun entirely intended) Overall, the Escapists is a very well planned game, and I would give it a 9.5/10.

Mouldy Toof and Team17- thanks for entertaining me!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally Early access done right.
Regular updates, it already got two prison maps !
Dev is posting weekly updates too.
This game remembers me of the old 2d metal gear solid games.
Your a prisoner and have to escape. But you have to watch your back, because the guards can get supsicious quite quickly!
There are daily routines like prison job , workout , food times etc
But the fun part starts when you leave those routines and start to discover the prison. There are many areas to discover.
Outside court with several job places. Inside areas with kitchen , workout rooms. And you can even visit several floors.
Fun and entertaining. Everyday you discover new craft recipes and tools to make.
Best thing it seems that's the job of one dude !

TL;DR
Basically its a blend of 2d metal gear and terraria. Sneaking mechanics with tons of craft recipes and discovery
At that price its a steal!

Edit: It got now tons of prisons. It had so many updates i cant even follow up all the prisons. I think currently it got round about five different prisons and now even a prison break race event started!
So obviously still recommended and the updates are amazing :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is an amazing game and it is so much fun to play.  Here's a few pros and cons that I have put together after about 18 hours of gameplay:

Pros
- Cheap
- Multiple prisons to escape from
- You get to name your character (who doesn't love that)
- Controls are simple and easy to learn
- The feeling of success after escaping
- Early Access means that they are going to add lots of new content (YAY)

Cons
- Addicting
- All of the other prisoners act the same
- It doesn't even seem like gaurds have a pattern
- Other than getting all your contraband taken away from you, going to solitary has pretty much no drawbacks

I really like this game and I'm excited to see how it turns out.  Oh, I almost forgot,  YOU SHOULD BUY IT.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe Escapists is a great game. It had me hooked the moment I saw it. I always love prison games where you have to try and escape any way you can. The game looks nice and all of the prisons have a good layout. It has good gameplay mechanics like the heat system for the guards. I was going to  come off the game but i kept saying just one more day to try and escape! The only thing i think they should change is the start when it teaches you how to play (we need a more in depth start to the game) I think its cool how you can pick your Escapist and name him and that you also can name every other person in the prison. The crafting system is ok but i wish some things did not cost so much brain power. The system for stats is ok but somtimes its annoying when your stats all go down. I think this game is worth getting if you are looking for a long game (because it might take you 30 days to escape!) Its a great deal! 9/10 :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honestly, this being my first purchase on Steam kinda bummed me out, as it seemed bigger than it was originally. Then update#2 happened, I saw the easier prison, and things started to click.

It's a game that lets you screw around however you want, but as time drags on you slowly start to formulate plans and ideas and start to recognize the weaknesses in the prison itself. Even though discovering things may take some time and you might be sent to solitary quite a few times, you start to understand what really matters and eventually you start to chip out ideas and plots of how you're going to escape. It's trial and error in a very pure form, and so far I'd say that this has me genuinely excited for where it goes from here. Worth every cent.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe escapist is an 8-bit adventure game based in a prison. You are able to chose from a variety of characters at the beginning to start off your quest to freedom. The aim of the game is to escape (incase you hadn't figured it out) and there are many ways to do this. There are no hints and tips in-game to get you out. you just need to use your initiative. You can go great escape, or steal the keys and hope you can out run the bullets. To do some of these tasks you need to buy equipment from the other inmates. This obviously requires money, which you earn by doing favours. While there are only a few different types of favours in the game at this time, they always seem rewarding, whether that be money or because you punched someone in the face during showers and outran the guards, i dont know. What i do know is the monotonous of buffing up is very.. well monotonus. It doesnt take just a few days to get your strength to a good standard where you can win a fight, same for  intelligence so you can craft certain objects. Other than this, this game has so much potential and i enjoy playing!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To start this review, I'll explain what The Escapists is. This game is an 8-bit simulation type. It makes you pick a character and gives you an insight in to prison life, as well as trying to escape the prison. You follow routines in order to keep the guards off of your back.

I like this game as:
1. It's original. I have never seen a game like this before and I tend to recommend original or uncopied games. The routines vary from prison to prison as well as the level of security so that not everything is a doppleganger of one another.
2. I find this game oddly addictive unlike some other games I have come across. I always try to escap with no avail yet I am always trying and trying again showing no signs of boredom whatsoever.
3. This game is in very early stages. There are some things I dislike about this game (e.g some items are too much of a challenge to obtain) but they will probably either be fixed or changed in later versions which means that most things that need fixing or changing will be fixd and changed by the time the game is finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access review, review is about the game at 2014-9-5

A very interesting concept with very interesting gameplay behind it. It has a lot of interesting methods to play and interactions. I've found it to be very good already, but it can use some more explanation on the interface. At the moment, it does not explain enough about how to perform actions when you have the tools to do them, so you'll mostly have to experiment. Even then, you'll be able to work out how things go easily enough.
Even when you figured it out, it's not easy to break out of prison!

Definitely worth getting already, with a lot of potential for later builds

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is a fun game though it does get quite repetitive. From what I've  played it seems like the basis of advancing to a higher tier in game in which you are well situated and familiar with the prison is crafting which requires you to find crafting plans, guess, or look it up on a wiki (which makes the game reliant on external sources other than itself for its gameplay hence not self-sustaining). The favors" or quests that you complete for other inmates are repetitive too as there are only two different types: A
hoursPlayed: there is a fun puzzle aspect to the game in figuring out how to sneak resources out from one of the three jobs you can pick as well as how to use these materials to access new areas and bypass locked doors. That being said
voteText: the worst thing in this game I would say is the leveling up system where you are literally performing menial button pressing over and over and over in order to level up and leveling up is essential as many jobs and crafting require you to have a minum level in the intellect area and you stand no chance in any type of combat (needed for the inmate quests) unless you have a high strength skill. It would be ok if you could achieve max level once and be done with it but it diminishes over time

reviewText:
The escapists is a game where you need to escape prison (duh), but there are many aspects of the game.
There are hardly any times where I found this game boring, but I do tend to get a lot of anger when my contraband is taken!
You need to locate many strategy to escape each prison step by step.
This is a great simulation of what prison would be (except for the dropping the soap).
I would also like to mention the DLC's and custom maps are even cooler. I like the fact that this company is trying there best to publish more content for people to play.

reviewText: the Escapists is hard later on but still fun. I guess it is like a RPG (role playing game), you have to grind all the time in the hardest prison which is bad but the game makes up for it by making you happy about escaping or finding the rare item that you need to craft something to help you escape which might make or brake the game for you. But you can't say its not a great feeling when you overcome something difficult. The art style is good for pixels, the top down point of view or POV is ok but not great. NPCs are cool with a like you meter as i call it it is a meter that tells you how much an NPC likes you and that will affect many things to how much discount you are given to if they will fight for you or look the other way if you beat someone up. If you do that the bar will go down a little bit they also make many references to a variety of movies, games, books and TV shows. Combat could use a better system because it is hit space and then left click once and you sit and wait it does not need to be a click click click to fight just like a power attack or quick attack would be fine and the layout of all prisons are great hugely different and detailed. this game gets a 9.0 maybe 9.4 for new update with building prisons but not many great ones yet hopefully in the future there is. Thanks for reading and i recommend this game. I guess i have zero punctuation ha ha ha

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay...I LOVE this game!  The 18+ hours showing on my review has been accrued in roughly a day and a half, despite my hectic schedule, my family's schedules and the additional game hindering chaos three kids provide. Despite my varied, somewhat conflicting, game library on Steam (which I share with my family, teen daughter included and yes, those are the anime VN novels in my library) I am generally a Fantasy/Sci-Fi RPG and FPS/RPG gamer (truthfully, it's story and a heavy immersion factor that I look for in a game) and yet I have become absolutely addicted to this fantastic little strategy game!  It reminds me of the simple fun games used to be.
Having been a gamer since the days of Amiga, Atari and Nintendo, it has become a rare thing, in recent years, for me to stumble upon a game that can hold my interest past the two hour mark...and this one certainly has.  I am now obsessed with figuring out all of the illegal contraband I can assemble from toothbrushes, wires, toliet paper, duct tape, super glue, etc., and am extremely, mischievously pleased when I can successfully beat a fellow inmate, for a favor or for an item I want, or when I beat a guard, take his key, imprint it into my putty, place it back on his person and get back to my exercise routine, no one the wiser but myself and my unfortunate victim...not to mention the ever-present goal behind all of my subterfuge and mayhem; escape!
I still cannot believe this was only an 18mg download  o.O  ...and it's far more entertaining than innumerable games that take up far more voluminous amounts of space on my hard drive than 18mgs!
As this game is in its early access stage of development, I fervently hope that the devs only add and never detract a thing from this game. People may complain about the pixelated graphics, but in my opinion, it keeps the tone clear; this is just a fun, clever game...not American Me or Shawshank Redemption, (however, there are some references to famous jail break movies within the game. ;-)
Remember the hour, day and week consuming fun of Earthbound or the original Final Fantasy & Super Mario Brothers, which always left you feeling frustrated, entertained and happy all at once?  Simple concept, tough to accomplish...so much to discover and do as you fight your way to the ultimate end goal of beating the game...The Escapists is so very much like those good old games of yesteryear.
Do yourself a favor...Give this wonderfully entertaining and amusing game a try!  It's not flashy or on the cutting edge of gaming tech, but it is enormously fun, frivolous and entertaining...something video games once were and rarely are these days.

Good game, but still needs work.

Pros:
Crafting is well organised,
Almost everything can be interacted with to some extent,
Potential for lots of playtime,

Somehow, breaking down walls in other inmates cells gets linked back to you,

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Literally one of the best games I've ever played.

You're in a prison and you have to escape, yeah, yeah, yeah. But it is  wayyyy  harder than you think. You gotta be elaborate, intelligent, and clever to escape, so you're probably not gonna escape at first. But that's what makes it so addicting. You always try to find new stuff and initiate your plan, and as soon as you start...

A guard or nighttower knocks you out. You're wake up with nothing you had equipped besides the stuff in your cell desk. You rage yet start again, finding out a new plan to escape or just go on with prison life.

That's what makes this game so enjoyable. There are so many different ways you can escape that once you find one, you stik to it until you fail and make another fail. It's like one big cycle that's broken once you escape. But the repeatedness isn't annoying.

The music is also great too, it sets a nice ambience for each activity in the prison, and kinda funny when you're trying to beat up a guard or something and the same music just goes on.

Overall,  amazing  game (considering it's still early access) by Mouldy Toof Studios, and I'd really recommend getting it. It's worth the 15 dollars.

10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The prisons are all fun and different, the characters have some of the funniest dialogue I've seen in a video game. You play the game at your own pace, do what you want, when you want. The crafting system is great and simple, the favor system gives you things to do when your bored, or to make some extra cash. Jobs are also a thing, you can be a mailman, a janitor, and much more! You will earn a lot of enemies in prison, but maybe some friends along the way as well!
The only things that are cons for me are as followed:
- It will sometimes take forever to get what you need, the things people sell are most of the time just useless for what you need.
- When trying to escape, if the guards find you, you are automatically caught and put in confinement without a chance to fight back, I feel that you should atleast be able to put up a fight!
- The jobs Janitor" and "Gardener" are all based off of luck

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Must-Buy game.

Pumping Iron, clipping guards and taking your clothes off and running around the prison whilst guards are chasing you are only a few things that make up The Escapists.


What makes this game so worth your 10 bucks? First of all, it's pixelated. If you're like me, pixelated games will make your heart melt like butter on pancakes. Secondly, it has that sandbox feel, but also a prison architect kind of security system, topped off with humourous remarks and a reason to do everything.


It's extremely PC-space friendly as it only takes a mere 18mb to run. You can still enjoy the game whether its your first time playing, or if you had already completed the game more than 10 times.


Let me recap :

Whats good :
-Extremely addictive.
-Space friendly.
-Indie.
-PIXELATED!
-Sandbox-y?
-Challenging, as well as entertaining.
-Humorous Interaction.
-Different types of weapons/contraband.
-Can get naked.
-Only 9.99!

What needs improvent:
-Music, I turned it off after an hour or so.
-Like to see this become co-op.
-Characters get buggy occasionally.


This game has lots of potential, and it's only in early acess! What are you waiting for? Buy it, damnit!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a brilliant, cute, light-hearted game all about escaping prison. It uses the classic 8-bit graphics combined with a top-down view and fantastic gameplay features of today. Believe me, you really should get this game. It's definitely kid-friendly, meaning that there isn't any foul language and the fighting that exists in the game is cartoony. Don't worry, though! It is still ridiculously fun (and funny) to play, and many adults play it.

I'd suggest getting it as soon as you can. It's definitely worth the money.

//Ron

reviewText:
If you're not sure whether or not to get this game, you should. Before I bought it I was contemplating whether or not this was a good investment, and trust me, it is.

You are a prisoner in a prison (duh). Your plan is to escape from the prison. It is a very challenging task as I, myself, still has not found a way to escape after 3 hours of gameplay. If you want an engaging game that you know that you will never get bored of for the next year or so, then I would recommend this game.  If you are looking for a story or multiplayer (the game doesn't have multiplayer for now), then I don't recommend it. In this game there is no set story, it's just a player controlled game.

If you are like games that are challenging, then I completely recommend this game for you. If you are looking for good graphics, story, or multiplayer gameplay, then I don't recommend you buying.

Otherwise I rate this game an 8.5/10
